required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Treatment of Eating Disorders by Physical Activity and Nutrition Counseling
clinical_study.official_title: Treatment of Eating Disorders - a Randomised, Controlled, Prospective Study

collaborator.agency: The Norwegian Women's Public Health Association

oversight_info.authority: Norway:National Committee for Medical and Health Research Ethics

brief_summary.textblock:
"Eating disorders" includes anorexia nervosa, bulimia nervosa, binge eating and eating disorders not otherwise specified (EDNOS). Common to all is the intensively occupation to control food intake, body image and body weight. Most people with this kind of disorder don't reach for professional help, or there may be more than 4 years before they do. Cognitive behavior therapy is the foremost method of treatment of eating disorders, but up to 30% of the patients don't respond to this. The investigators find it important to identify science based alternatives of therapy, as this may reduce the health concern, and broaden the choice of therapy methods. A former study by Sundgot-Borgen et al in 2002, found guided physical activity to reduce symptoms of bulimia nervosa just as good as the traditional cognitive therapy.
The primary objective of the project is to see whether the combination of physical activity and nutritional education is more effective in treating eating disorders, than cognitive therapy.
Secondly, the investigators want to see whether there are any differences with regard to the individual satisfaction of treatment method, and to associated costs.

detailed_description.textblock: Subjects are recruited through primary doctors, social media and newspapers, and will be included continuously by screening interviews. There will be a randomization into two treatment groups (cognitive behavior, or physical activity and nutrition education) to be followed for 16 weeks. Each week includes one meeting of group therapy (90 minutes) and homework related to treatment, and for 4 weeks midway there will be two therapy meetings pr week (a total of 20 meetings). Post tests are planned at week 17, and at 6, 12, 18 and 36 months after treatment.

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Single Group Assignment, Masking: Open Label, Primary Purpose: Treatment

primary_outcome.measure: Effectiveness of treatment, evaluated through the change in eating disorder symptoms
primary_outcome.time_frame: Pre-test in week 0, Post-tests are planned at week 17, and at 6, 12, 18 and 36 months after intervention.
primary_outcome.description: Change in ED-symptoms are evaluated through screening and surveys: Eating disorder examination (EDE), EDE-questionaire (Episodes of binge eating, episodes of purging, concern for body weight and appearance)(Fairburn, 2008), Clinical Impairment Assessment (CIA) (Fairburn, 2008), Eating Disorder Inventory-3 (EDI) (Garner, 2004), Eating Disturbance Scale (EDS-5) (Rosenvinge et al., 2000), DSM-5 (APA, 2013)

secondary_outcome.measure: Expectations of treatment method for eating disorders
secondary_outcome.description: Interview on the expectations the patients have to the specified treatment method of eating disorders (arm of intervention) (Clinton 2001)

secondary_outcome.measure: Experiences of the treatment method for eating disorders
secondary_outcome.description: Interview on the experiences the patients have to the specified treatment method of eating disorders (arm of intervention) (Clinton 2001)
Calculation of the directly and indirectly cost related to treatment method

Calculation of the directly and indirectly cost related to treatment method

secondary_outcome.measure: Global measurement of change in general psychopathology
secondary_outcome.description: Beck's Anxiety Inventory, Beck Depression Inventory (BDI), Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale, QoL (Diener), SF-36, Utrecht Coping List, Resilience Scale for Adults

coerciveness scale from Therapeutic Factor Inventory (Lese & MacNair-Semands, 2000).
Working AIliance Inventory (Horwath & Greenberg, 1989), The Revised Helping Alliance Questionnaire (HSq-II) (Luborsky et al., 1996)

secondary_outcome.measure: Experiences of the treatment method for eating disorders
secondary_outcome.description: Interview on the experiences the patients have to the specified treatment method of eating disorders (arm of intervention) (Clinton 2001)
Calculation of the directly and indirectly cost related to treatment method

other_outcome.time_frame: Pretest (week 0), post-test (week 17) and at 6, 12 and 36 months after treatment
other_outcome.description: Status of 1 repetition maximum, 1RM, muscular strength in squats, bench press and seated row

other_outcome.time_frame: Pre-test in week 0, Post-tests are planned at week 17, and at 6, 12 and 36 months after intervention.
other_outcome.description: The Balke Treadmill performance evaluation test, The Borg scale (Borg, 1982)

other_outcome.time_frame: Pre-test in week 0, Post-tests are planned at week 17, and at 6, 12 and 36 months after intervention.
other_outcome.description: Reasons for Exercise Inventory, Compulsive Exercise test

other_outcome.time_frame: Pre-test in week 0, Post-test are planned at week 17, and 6, 12, 18 and 36 months post-treatment
Pre-test, in week 8 of treatment, and post-test (week 17, and at 6,12,18 and 36 months post-treatment)
other_outcome.description: Tanita scale (weekly weight registration will also be kept in each arm of treatment)

other_outcome.time_frame: Pre-test, in week 8 of treatment, post-test (week 17, and at 6,12,18 and 36 months post-treatment)
other_outcome.description: Blood test to identify nutritional status of iron, cholesterol and triglycerides, and vitamin-D

other_outcome.time_frame: Pre-test, week 8 of treatment, post-test (week 17, and at 6,12,18 and 36 months post-treatment))
other_outcome.description: Blood test to evaluate hormonal status of estradiol, progesterone, CTX, P1nP and leptin

other_outcome.time_frame: Pre-test, each 3rd week in treatment, post-test at 17.th week, and post-treatment (6,12, 18 and 36 months post-treatment)
other_outcome.description: 24 hour recall interview: interview on the intake of food and beverage during the past 24 hours.

arm_group.description: Treatment with small groups following a modified protocol first described by Fairburn 2008
Physical activity and nutrition counseling: Treatment with guided physical activity and nutrition counseling in small groups

intervention.description: Following group-modified protocol for cognitive behavioral therapy, CBT, first described by Fairburn 2008, modified by Modum Bad, Norway.

Guided physical activity and nutrition counseling, to improve healthy lifestyle and help stabilizing a healthy weight. To further strengthen selfimage through positive experiences, to improve mood through endorphins and stress relief in exercise

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Women,
- BMI 17,5-35,
- Age of 18-35 years,
- DSM-5 criteria of bulimia nervosa,
- DSM-5 criteria of Binge eating disorder,
- Living nearby Norwegian School of Sports Sciences, NSSS, in Oslo (Norway)
Exclusion Criteria:
- Age <18 and >35 years
- BMI <17,5 and >35
- Pregnancy
- Competing/experienced athlete
- Anorexia nervosa
- Currently, or during the past 2 years, in active treatment
- Other personality disturbances
- Suicidality

link.description: The Norwegian Women's Public Health Association

results_reference.citation: Sundgot-Borgen J, Rosenvinge JH, Bahr R, Schneider LS. The effect of exercise, cognitive therapy, and nutritional counseling in treating bulimia nervosa. Med Sci Sports Exerc. 2002 Feb;34(2):190-5.
